qas.question: When did youtube first require the user to have a google account before posting a comment?
The changes to the google+ additions allowed uploaders to better moderate and what to comments?
There were better sorting functions put in place in 2013 to make sure what kind of comments appeared on top?
What is youtube co-founder Karim's first name?
How many thumbs down votes did youtube's official statement about the new commenting system get within two days?
What did Google implement on November 13, 2006?

plausible_answers.text: why the fuck do I need a google+ account to comment on a video?

qas.question: What did Karim Jawed post on his YouTube Channel in response to the policy change?

plausible_answers.text: Google+ is nowhere near as popular a social media network as Facebook, but it's essentially being forced upon millions of YouTube users

qas.question: What did Melvin Chase note about Google+?

plausible_answers.text: Discussion forums across the Internet are already bursting with outcry against the new comment system

qas.question: What did Melvin Chase say about the discussion forums?

context: On <a0_0>November 6, 2013<a0_0/>, Google implemented <b5_0>a new comment system<b5_0/> that requires all YouTube users to use a Google+ account in order to comment on videos and making the comment system Google+ oriented. The changes are in large part an attempt to address the frequent criticisms of the quality and tone of YouTube comments. They give creators more power to moderate and <a1_0>block<a1_0/> comments, and add new sorting mechanisms to ensure that better, <a2_0>more relevant discussions<a2_0/> appear at the top. The new system restored the ability to include URLs in comments, which had previously been removed due to problems with abuse. In response, YouTube co-founder <a3_0>Jawed<a3_0/> Karim posted the question "<b6_0>why the fuck do I need a google+ account to comment on a video?<b6_0/>" on his YouTube channel to express his negative opinion of the change. The official YouTube announcement received <a4_0>20,097<a4_0/> "thumbs down" votes and generated more than 32,000 comments in two days. Writing in the Newsday blog Silicon Island, Chase Melvin noted that "<b7_0>Google+ is nowhere near as popular a social media network as Facebook, but it's essentially being forced upon millions of YouTube users<b7_0/> who don't want to lose their ability to comment on videos" and "<b8_0>Discussion forums across the Internet are already bursting with outcry against the new comment system<b8_0/>". In the same article Melvin goes on to say:
